output: Thank you, Mr. President. I strongly welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, which is to get to the bottom of the causes of malnutrition, obesity, and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in food policy in Europe, whether we are discussing Ne Proffi, food labeling, or certain aspects of the White Book, we tend to adopt a highly one-sided approach.
We are attempting to resolve the problems we face in Europe through product policy.
I believe that it is fundamentally flawed policy to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Amendments demonstrate that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or rather balanced and unbalanced, ways of eating.
Our approach should be.
The causes of malnutrition are multifaceted.
Attempting to rectify this by guiding consumers through product labeling, or even through advertising bans, regulations, or varying VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we are doing here should not preempt the discussion on the labeling regulation, but everything we do here should fall under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their dietary habits?

A traffic-light labeling system that suggests to him that I am now facing a good or bad product, in my opinion, is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I wish for a balanced approach here and the realization that relying solely on product policy will not take us any further. Thank you very much, Senior Krammer, for this insight.

Mr. President, Vice-President, dear colleagues,

Budget control has no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points, firstly, our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building up the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We do not want to be where we are today in two years' time. That is why this point is of utmost importance to us.
The second point is the reliability declaration for the overall budget following the graduated control procedure, involving the national audit courts.
It would be desirable if we could make decisive progress in the remaining six months of the Commission's term or, at the very least, agree on a common approach.
One does become modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to provide more support to the lower administrative levels of the member states in the implementation of EU law.
It becomes apparent that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law. This is also the reason for the high error rates.
fourth point, external aid here, I would like to address the Kosovo in particular and the issue of cooperation with the United Nations
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo, and I would like to announce in advance that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge of the budget.
I believe that we have remained far below the capabilities of the European Union thus far and that we urgently need to catch up on our efforts in this area.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among member states in the fight against fraud.
We have homework here, primarily for the ladies and gentlemen of the Council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis for the regulation on fraud prevention in November. Then we need to consider jointly how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this field.
was at least our shared desired outcome so far
Mr. President! India and Europe need more and better contacts at all levels, especially also at the level of so-called ordinary people.
business travelers, tourists, students, and so onâ€”a brief note on this: it is also relevant for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations, ones that are effective, not just token measures.
It would therefore be a reasonable and truly necessary step to finally abolish the meaningless liquid regulations and come up with something more sensible.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, indeed rigged, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.
At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between people and to democratize the country by seriously exploring the possibility of
Reduction of visa fees for Belarusian citizens, whose entry into the Schengen area should be considered, and thus prevent the increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like to first distance myself from the spirit of a statement made just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding our labor market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer and more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social binding force of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as primary European law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the ECJ, and not be content with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms, free movement.
We do not change this. Social fundamental rights are, just like freedom rights and human rights, not to be restricted by the freedoms of the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time for the introduction of a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
It is time to amend the Posted Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements are not limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Mr. President, I would like to associate myself with the expressions of thanks to rapporteur Doris Ba, which have already been rightly conveyed by many of my colleagues.
We have in her someone who hopefully does not forget the passion, but invests a great deal of passion in this space.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also stated that there have been some advancements, including in the field of police cooperation.
This is important to ensure that real life on the ground can function in a reasonable manner.

I still believe, however, that we must continually remind our conversation partners in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they themselves must contribute a great deal more, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal work within the ethnic group, is something we must continually demand.
It is not the case that everyone tries to go their own way.
And integration into regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is also important.
Madam President! The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not grow as much as it has.
We need to ensure that it is reduced in size.
In this context, the ombudsman has an important role to play, especially when and where he performs it well.
It is also primarily about ensuring that we have the commitment and discretion of the ombudsman.
It is about not raising expectations too high that no one can then meet.

It is also about ensuring that, wherever shortcomings have occurred in the administration of the European institutions, these are addressed and, where possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can then guarantee and satisfy the citizen.
Previous practice has shown that the Ombudsman fulfills this task diligently and competently.
We can hope that this remains the case. We thank you and the rapporteur for this report.

It seems like you've forgotten to provide the German text that needs to be translated. Please supply the German text so I can proceed with the translation. 

(Note: Once you provide the German text, I will give you the English translation without any additional explanations, adhering to your instructions.)
Colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or being propped up with billions from the national treasury. Sales are plummeting, and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But it is not just the market that has failed; the prevailing political system also seems incapable of learning from its mistakes.

We are of the opinion, even with such interjections, that you do not particularly wish to stand out. We are of the view that serious mistakes were made in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such an error is the structural decoupling of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without at least partially harmonizing tax and expenditure policies at the same time.
I believe the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have intensified enormously.
What we need now is indeed better coordination of economic policy and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, in addition, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally brought under control again.
the second significant error lies in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact

Anyone who believes that a consolidation of households is inevitable in times like these is clearly living in another world. Nothing would be more fatal than to respond to this economic crisis by now also implementing public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and to improve the situation of socially disadvantaged people in Europe.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank, and furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, such that in the future, growth and employment must be promoted as equally as price stability.
The current crisis also presents an opportunity for far-reaching reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, President-in-Office of the Council, esteemed colleagues! Indeed, the automotive industry is in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further exacerbated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And therefore, for this key European industry, we also need European solutions to overcome the crisis.
Nearly all automotive conglomerates exhibit European structures.

To make necessary investments in environmental protection, which has been mentioned several times today, and to enable the development of environmentally friendly and resource-efficient technologies, automakers require public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, which is very important, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is particularly in the supplier industry, within small and medium-sized enterprises, that jobs are being created and innovations are taking place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
At the last plenary session, the President of the Council proposed a measure to protect key industries.
a good proposal, in my opinion, if one consistently follows this line of thought, it means a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
That would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protection instrument is currently being opposed by the European Commission.
My question to the Commission is: Will the European Commission, despite the crisis in the automotive industry, maintain its legal action, or will it now change course in light of the crisis?

Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, and Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues! Indeed, it has now become a tradition to note that the European Union's budget for the past financial year was implemented efficiently and effectively.
We must note that in the relationship between expenditures at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of reliability cannot be issued repeatedly.

I remember conversations with the former president of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, based on the structure, it is absolutely impossible to provide a reliability declaration.
Therefore, we should already think together about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a reliability declaration, when justified, can also be achieved.
And here we must, of course, draw a few distinctions right from the start.
Firstly, a budget that comprises around 95% subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national, regional, or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who in the new financial period have demanded much more autonomy from us, as the criticism of the last funding period was that too much was centrally controlled.
This of course also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
In the third area of discussion, I would like to briefly touch upon
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These, too, are things that are often lumped together.
I am also annoyed when things that are not strictly necessary are funded with EU money.
That, however, was not fraud, it was waste.

Therefore, those responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, the Member States, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only those projects are funded that truly create added value for the region.
Therefore, we should certainly also consider converting parts of structural policy to interest-free loans.
If you have to repay member states, then only promote what you genuinely need. Thank you very much.
it is not just me who finds it difficult to join in the self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to overcoming the financial market crisis
leaves because if Europe, if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question of responsibility and how all this could have come about.
It is simply not true that all the problems we face are akin to a tsunami and are naturally occurring; rather, they are man-made.
And amidst all the regulatory fervor that has characterized this Union, one wonders: Why was no action taken when banks began crossing national borders on a significant scale?
Why was no action taken, despite appropriate warnings, as derivatives became so insidiously integrated?
I vividly recall that Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz addressed all these points.
There was silence, there was a taboo.
One should focus on this, as the key to finding solutions in the future lies solely in recognizing one's own mistakes.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen! Mr. Commissioner! My question concerns your opinion on Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a secondary currency.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem between these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity?
My third question is: Don't you think that a reduction in value-added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
Would it not be more reasonable to consider tax reductions for our businesses and our employees, to pay investment premiums, and to correspondingly implement progressive depreciation?

reprioritizes and especially increases low-value economic goods by a factor of 10, so that fictitious profits are not taxed, the money remains in the companies, and thus wages can also be better paid.
Madam President! The comprehensive report makes it clear how many human rights violations occur around the world every single day.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and it calls on us to redouble our efforts.
For this reason as well, I would like to advocate for the current Sub-Committee on Human Rights to be established as a Main Committee.
Today, we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hojia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is incarcerated, he was unable to assume personal responsibility.
Shame on China! And tomorrow, a debate on human rights violations in Russia will take place here.
In our relations with these two countries, we must give not only economic interests but especially human rights a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hodjia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

As the rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about fighting fraud and then no one does anything.
Or the experience that member states meticulously calculate their payments to the European Union, but when it comes to spending this money, they put on their spending pants.
and it even makes it easy for fraudsters, for example, by taking an average of 36 months before irregularities are reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We aim for efficient fraud prevention, which includes proactive measures.
We aim for member states to prioritize fraud prevention and for us to collectively discuss the requirements and challenges associated with it.
We aim to foster greater interest among national judicial authorities in following up on OLA mediation outcomes.
In the case of online platforms, there should no longer be legal loopholes as has been the case hitherto.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal foundations to fulfill its tasks.
We aim for an agency that can collaborate seamlessly and efficiently with the member states.
Our position on legal basis 17399 encompasses all these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation as the cornerstone of the agency's fraud prevention efforts, in collaboration with the Council.
We call on the Council to incorporate our opinion. We urge the Council to initiate discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We aim to bring the problems of OLAF to a resolution.
I thank all the factions of this House for also supporting this in a resolution, which we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech presidencies of the Council to pick up the ball thrown by Parliament and return it.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and presented by the Council Working Group.
From our side, I can express our interest in a swift conclusion to this regulation and assure you of our willingness to engage in constructive discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidating all OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, would mean a further significant loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Ola will soon celebrate his tenth birthday.
A consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take the fight against fraud too seriously for that.
We therefore want to achieve what is feasible now, in cooperation with the Council.
sincere thanks
Mr. President, I would like to pick up on a remark made earlier by my Austrian colleague, Paul RÃ¼big.

We spend less than 1 percent of the European gross domestic product on Europe, while at the same time demanding that an ever-growing number of tasks for an increasing number of member states be addressed by the European Union.
This calculation cannot add up. It is therefore also highly implausible that we have been pursuing a course of austerity for many years, but this austerity is not limited to prudent spending.
Our funds are not being used for their intended purpose, but rather to enable finance ministers to collect money at the end of the year and incorporate it into their national budgets.
We have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not actually been adequately funded for in budgetary terms for years.
I believe that the European Union's information funds should be significantly increased if we truly want to engage European citizens with Europe.
There are numerous tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchanges where Europe could be deployed.
Which, in the justice sector, is making headway in an area that has traditionally been reserved for the state.
This reflects the changed living conditions of the people in our Union.
But, and this observation has already been made several times, integration must not interfere too much with traditionally established structures, especially those that are functional.
Not everything should be swept under the rug.
Public deeds and public notaries are structured quite differently across many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notariat as a public deed office has a long tradition and a high level of security and trust.
This should not be put at risk unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness yes, but with a sense of proportion.
Thank you very much, Madam President, esteemed colleagues! Pesticides were and remain essential operational tools in agriculture.
Farmers require a minimum selection of plant protection products, as it concerns the protection of the domestic cultivated landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the preservation of resources.
We often conduct discussions about chemicals at a highly irrational level.
To obtain reasonable results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the original parliamentary position would have been fatal, resulting in a broad ban on pesticides, leading to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was reached in the trilogue negotiations.
It is welcome that we have retained the three-zone system, albeit with significant exceptions for member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different at this point. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not preempt a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances but actually give the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically based definition.
Otherwise, we are stretching the precautionary principle beyond its limits at this point.
And finally, I regret that we are not tempted to initiate an impact assessment of the agreement now reached. Thank you very much.
On the last occasion when there were corresponding expressions of opinion during the visit of a head of government or head of state, the President of this House intervened massively.
At that time, it was about a matter that was of great importance to him, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When today the president, the sovereign elected president of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not intervene.
Do you know what this is?
This is not democracy, it is arbitrariness, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
For minutes, children and politics rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The topic of children is of utmost importance to citizens across Europe.
Politicians rank children's concerns low on their agenda, as we can once again observe here.

I am not aware of any country that has a dedicated ministry for children's affairs. Even within the Commission, there is no specific representative tasked with advocating for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In parliament, the topic of children is scattered across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to specifically draw the Commission's attention to the fact that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the situation in Barcelona today.
In our parliamentary working group on the Quality of Childhood, we have found the following: Our children live in a highly complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here and now is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb to the very top of the social ladder or fall right to the bottom.
It can remain within its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
An individual may follow a similar life path to that of their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite sex or of the same sex.
All of this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we launched the Association of Europe.
The diversity that characterizes us Europeansâ€”this diversity has become a defining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be integrated into the pedagogy of child educators and teachers.
This is currently still being taken into account far too little.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed breaking under the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we need to press the reset button back to the start.
Let's approach this topic once again completely without prejudice, following the motto "Unity through Diversity."

Moreover, I ask all my fellow European Parliamentarians to advocate not only for gender mainstreaming, but also for child mainstreaming, especially now in the time of the global financial crisis, as we would otherwise burden our children with immeasurable debt. Thank you!
Mr. President, I want to keep this brief.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude for the constructive debate contributions I have heard here.
I would like to convey two messages at the conclusion. Firstly, I expressly thank the Commissioner for not speaking out against the concept of minimum requirements of the safety net in principle.
This proposal is neither a devil's concoction nor a bureaucratic monster.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That's why I would like to advertise this once again at this point.
and the second point I would like to make, and this is directed at my British friends, is that all parties must unite.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can understand that, for a certain period of time, a country might prioritize energy security over adherence to air pollutant limit values.
I have great understanding of this.
I would be the last person to deny Your Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we did not do precisely that.
This conversation never took place over the past four months.
I would like to ask you, in this second reading, to remain open-minded at this point and say, let's discuss a compromise at this juncture.

for the completely irrational resistance from my perspective, which cannot be justified from a competition or environmental policy standpoint, to give up the fundamental opposition to minimum standards.
I believe that this is the point at which we can reach a compromise, which I hope we will also achieve in the end during the second reading.
By the way, I do not share the view that we should not seek a compromise in the first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.
I do not wish to conclude this legislative term as rapporteur and leave a piece of legislation to the next Parliament that involves a text which is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I kindly request your support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour. Thank you very much.

Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I believe the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus packages being put together across Europe is, of course, who will ultimately receive the money?
We will issue further blank checks to the banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer.
And corporations and high-income earners should be further relieved, even though they have already been fattened up for years across Europe through tax gifts.

The more money that is squandered on such purposes, the more predictable it becomes that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalizationâ€”it is precisely this policy that has increasingly concentrated incomes among the top 10,000, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing exactly the same policies with minor modifications? I think they simply haven't understood anything.
The exact opposite is required.

Instead of using taxpayer money to bail out banks and buy up their toxic assets, financial resources should be directed towards the renovation of schools and hospitals, and towards the ecological transformation of the European economy.

Whenever private companies receive public funds, it must be a given that no tax money is granted without employment guarantees, and above all, no tax money should be allocated without the acquisition of public property rights. This ensures that the state, and most importantly, the general public, can benefit from future profits.
The very best economic stimulus program that could exist at present would be a radical redistribution of incomes and wealth from the top to the bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be reduced, rather than continually promoted.
We need higher minimum wages and we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have arisen, and not the vast majority of citizens who, after all, never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the only economically rational policy.
It is the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamics.

Mr. President! In early March, political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be charged once again on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public hearing date was set for March 31st.
On the same day, the human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low value it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be employed not only to deny justice but also to suppress opponents of the regime, and the EU is thereby complicit.
Lord, Commissioner, many thanks, dear colleagues! I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again emphasizing the ban on animal testing.

as she pointed out, because it reminds me that this is the third amendment to cosmetics legislation that I have been able to accompany; the sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the amendment to a regulation.
And we did manage to ban animal testing.
We have succeeded, for example, in ensuring that consumers know how long a product is still usable by seeing a small can with a number indicating how much longer it is valid.

I am also addressing this to some colleagues, in particular Ms. Reuteko Reutova, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Labels are never warning signs at any time. If a product is not safe, it may not be on the market, it may not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and free from harm.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to make a choice.
This is democracy, and this is its freedom of choice.
I believe it would be very good legislation.
I have attempted to make the process highly transparent.
I have attempted, as Ms. Crostet also mentioned, to reconcile differing opinions.

For my part, I am committed to creating legislation that is good for everyone: for the consumers of the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
Colleague Stellhard, I'll say it again: Yes, the DO affects everyone differently, but the statement that it keeps us sweat-free still holds true.
Therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my wrinkle depth around the eyes after a week in Strasbourg are reasonably realistic and reliable.
Once again, I extend my gratitude to the Commissioner, not only for the explanations he provided to the colleagues and fellow members but also to my female colleagues who did most of the work.
I thank them very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! The report by Mr Vanisterol concerning the Green Paper and the future shape of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports of the Regional Committee in recent years.
We agree with the basic concept of the Green Book, which posits that territorial cohesion is indeed about fostering a polycentric development of
to ensure overall and sustainable development of the sovereign territories with their diverse characteristics and peculiarities while preserving their richness.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance for transition regions crossing the 75-threshold will be implemented.
a percentage of the gross national product must be set aside to create the necessary conditions for these regions to gain a clear status, thereby ensuring greater security in their development.
In the report by colleague Krehe on obstacles in accessing the structural funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, which applicants face when submitting their applications.

The utilization of structural funds is hampered by issues such as excessive administrative burden, numerous complex regulations, slow and cumbersome centralized administration within the member states.
Various recommendations are addressed to the Commission regarding effective measures to be taken in order to eliminate these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.

For the first time, project managers are required to retain their project documentation for a period of ten years in order to have it available for inspections, which will also be carried out by the Commission.
For smaller projects in particular, this is an excessively bureaucratic effort.
Correct, that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the evaluation criteria of the EU Commission for innovative projects cause significant problems.
In the case of innovative projects, the same evaluation criteria should not be applied as for other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different happens here.

Madam President! When Europe allocates funds, and especially when Member States invest significant amounts of money to aid the automotive industries in their time of crisis, it should not solely focus on preserving the status quo and ensuring the survival of these industries. Rather, it must address a range of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about finding employment for people, and they also need to secure this employment, preferably long-term.
To achieve this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transport system more strongly than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives as well, so that we do not have to face accusations in a few years' time. We should have thought about all of this many years ago, then we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Thank you very much, Madam President. It would be kind if you could also grant me the additional half minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, has just been given.
The Commission has put forward a sound proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.
Unfortunately, some amendments seek to supplement this proposal with requirements that are not in line with the objectives of the regulation or even aim to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with respect to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO laws, specifically the demand for special labeling of novel foods derived from animals fed with genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it. I think
In principle, anything that relates to GMO legislation should not be addressed in the Novel Foods Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, submitted a proposal to specifically exclude corresponding new plant-based products from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this House misuse the Nobel Food Regulation for election campaign purposes.
It is apparently also the case with Amendments 62 and ninety, for which the Greens have requested a roll-call vote.
Which esteemed colleagues do you intend to expose in this manner?
My faction, too, has always advocated for the consumer's right to know what is contained in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano-origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although Amendment 62 somewhat clumsily attempts to pre-empt my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling by Noble Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my faction approve the aforementioned motions, and I will include references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labeling in my report on the Food Information Regulation.
This is possible because we postponed the first reading on foot labeling to the next legislative term, against the will of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Briefly on cloning, it is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation accordingly, as otherwise they would fall under a legal vacuum.
Madam President, it is quite simple.
Those who do not wish for this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament should support my motion to amend the rules of procedure!

Madam President, Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! One thing must be made clear from the outset: The donation of food to those in need, especially in these economically challenging times, is not up for debate in the upcoming vote on our colleague Mr. Tschickerski's report.
Therefore, I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common approach within our group.
Therefore, I respect each fellow group member's personal decision to deviate from our planned rejection of the report and not to support it.
Why can I not agree with the result of the committee vote in this form?

final point I also very much welcome the fact that we have reached a consensus that we do not want a lawsuit industry modeled after the American system, with an annual turnover of 240 billion US dollars, from which only lawyers benefit in the end, and the consumer gains nothing.

Mr. President, I regret, along with the rapporteur Jules Savary, that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.

No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities to shape their transportation conditions.
We merely aim to contribute from the European side to ensure that reasonable, joint rules are followed when a municipality, a city, or a regional unit deems it necessary.
The principle of subsidiarity is not jeopardized.
What we aim to do here is to safeguard this principle.

I fully support the Commission's aim to create a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle to standardize the introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, underscores the urgency for me almost daily. But intelligent transportation systems can do much more.
They contribute to environmental sustainability, efficiency enhancement, improved safety, non-discriminatory competitiveness, and road freight and passenger transport.

Moreover, you support multimodality, among other things through the development of interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, inland waterways, and air traffic, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a joint task.

Building intelligent transport systems based on EU-wide binding, fundamental standards and minimum quality regulations improves the environment for innovation and provides planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transportation system services.

The action plan finally includes a timeline for the implementation of individual systems: A for road traffic safety, such as ESP and eCall, and B for continuity in traffic management. For instance, information...
Toll fees or parking management Avoid detour traffic. C The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will not only benefit professional drivers but enrich all road users.
The directive serves to establish detailed requirements for the coordinated, EU-wide mandatory introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.

However, beware: The introduction of intelligent transport systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.

Mr. President, for the first time since I have been a member of this House, I voted against the discharge of the Commission in the vote on the discharge. I would like to...
My reasons are primarily concerned with the manner in which the European Commission has handled the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, a high level of corruption, a significant amount of money, and a substantial sum of European funds that have gone missing.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in 2008.
In 2007, we lost a significant amount of money and are now dealing with barely existent control systems, or systems that function only intermittently.
In Romania, we are confronted with a high rate of corruption and issues within the justice system.
All this is to be attributed to the pre-accession process.

My goal is to set an example and to tell the European Commission that it needs to take a different approach for future accessions. I also want to convey to it that, based on observations in other countries, it could potentially achieve greater success if it so desires.

I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries in building financial control systems that deserve that name and to assist in eliminating the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a permanent problem and a constant source of concern for all of Europe on our hands. Thank you.

It seems to me, both for us as for the EU in general, but also for the Parliament here, to be a bit symptomatic that we automatically engage in discussions about situations in countries whose circumstances are not new.
Unfortunately, it is the case that very often subsequent events lead to our suddenly pouring into political forums in a wave-like manner, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to allow a failed airplane attack to trigger a general debate about Yemen alone.
I believe that we should be clear about the fact that it would be prudent for us to devise a strategy on how to handle this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a close analysis, specifically that it is a failed state where a government operates that no longer has control over large parts of the country. We should analyze for ourselves what risks arise for Europe from this situation.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging off the coast of Yemen, where piracy is apparently taking place.
Therefore, I believe it is up to us, and perhaps also to Ms. Ashton, to consider what we can do against these risks.
In my view, the primary question is: How can we support the government in Yemen to regain control of the country and mitigate these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country, of course, also need to be held. But I do not believe that it is truly meaningful or that we will be taken seriously if we now initiate a catalog of demands across all policy issues, from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
I believe that this will not lead to a solution in Yemen. Instead, we should focus on what specific help we can provide in the current situation to address an acute problem. Thank you.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries while at the same time destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.

Similarly, we can advocate for better healthcare to our heart's content, but if we hinder the trade of generic drugs or drive medication prices to unaffordable heights through patent extensions, our efforts will be in vain.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to a small degree, but they lead to deforestation and land-use change in developing countries, thereby causing more climate change, which we were precisely trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and arable land for food production.
At present, we, that is, the EU as a whole, are not particularly coherent.
The EU has recognized in theory for some time that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states: "When implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation."
We must be measured against this demand.
This year, we are reviewing the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without policy coherence, we will not succeed in keeping our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, as all those who enact and implement laws. Before deciding on a measure, there must be an impact assessment to enable us to identify potential negative effects of European legislation on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission, and Parliament that recognizes incoherences.
The Commission's work program on policy coherence is a good step forward.
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence in the interest of development means that in the fisheries reform, we must take greater account of the interests of the people on the ground and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing corporations.
It means that we need to dry up tax havens that are draining funds from developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the competencies of the Development Commissioner should be expanded, not restricted.
It also involves, for instance, enabling fair trade in the awarding of contracts within municipalities, as my colleague Heide RÃ¼le has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on members of the Commission and the Council to ensure they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us, the representatives, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to improve networking among the committees, and we require one or a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee adopted unanimously, makes many good proposals and brings us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.

Madam President, dear colleagues,

For months, we have been discussing the issue of driving and working hours in road transport.
I wonder what arguments are now being marshaled to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The latest argument is that one must urgently make changes here so that nothing changes.
Don't you notice, dear Ms. Bauer, how absurd this line of argument has become, how permeated it is with lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than extending the working hours of the self-employed.
In labor law, however, the principle has been for 150 years to protect people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and employed staff.
It is entirely irrelevant whether one is a self-employed person who is overworked or whether an employer overworks an employee driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, with regard to road traffic safety, it is claimed here that nothing could possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hardware store for hobbyists, and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws with the attitude of "Let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are designed to be hazardous, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who will be responsible for monitoring the relaxed regulations you are proposing on our roads in the future?
A state labor judge cannot today verify whether someone appears to be self-employed or independent without extensive review of the case files.
discontinue this nonsense; it's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent this morning for future negotiations regarding the extension of working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.

Clearly, today's focus is not on the traffic safety regulations concerning driving and rest periods, which all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to. Today, we are concerned with the regulation of working hours.
It is primarily an employee protection measure, serving solely to provide social protection for drivers and in no way relating to road safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Adherence to working hours for self-employed truck and bus drivers cannot be monitored without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a compelling reason why such monitoring should be carried out in the first place.

Restricting the permissible working hours of self-employed professional drivers, and potentially also self-employed craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament in this way, sends the wrong signal.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues! Just a few days ago, we were shocked by the television images showing vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries flooded by water.
People have lost their lives in the floods, and our deepest sympathies go out to their loved ones. Entire towns, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images. However, the immense damage must still be painstakingly eliminated.
In addressing damages of this magnitude, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
In the wake of the flood disaster of 1997, Poland and this time other Central European countries are once again affected by a major flood catastrophe.
We cannot yet control the weather, and floods are part of the natural behavior of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we must ask are, in awareness of the fact that these natural events can always occur, whether the right preventive measures are in place.
Damages from such natural events were affected and whether, for example, in landscape planning, the issues of sustainable disaster protection were given due consideration.
If aid is granted, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster to secure their livelihoods.
Then, however, more should be done at the European level, in international cooperation, to prevent damage caused by natural disasters, without stopping at national borders.

The fact that jointly operated preventive measures can provide protection is demonstrated by the flood protection along the Oder River, which has been jointly established there by Polish and German authorities so far.
But we are by no means at the end.
We do not need a European disaster protection agency.
The protection of its country from disasters should be the primary task of a government, which should also include the development of disaster plans.

However, the coordination of assistance in the event of damage and incidents should also undergo efficient European coordination, and the organizations that provide rapid and non-bureaucratic aid on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear their expenses.
Therefore, I support the Commissioner's plans, Ms. Georgieeva's plans, to implement these quickly.

A Europe without internal borders is not feasible without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed would be inconceivable, without efficient and future-proof transport systems on land, on water, and in the air.
In particular, for environmentally friendly rail transport, we need more community and less national selfishness.

is burning down houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who have left their homes and tried to flee the violence. All of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan once again cast a spotlight on the situation in Central Asia, which cannot leave us in the European Parliament indifferent.
On the contrary, we should be directing our full attention to the countries in this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but also consider all states on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
This is, for us, our commitment.
The Central Asian states, which only twenty years ago liberated themselves from the once oppressive and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.
Arbitrarily drawn borders by Stalin, without regard for the homeland of the peoples living there, apparently hinder coexistence within and outside the borders of these states.
Poverty corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions such as those in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, affecting hundreds of thousands.
The forced labor immigration, as now admitted in Kyrgyzstan, allows conflict resolution through the use of violence, leaving the path of these states into the future shrouded in question marks.
Here the European Union cannot merely watch.
If we do not want to allow these states' paths to lead into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to abandon the people there to permanent dictatorial regimes, we must commit fully.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we require contact with these states and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in her efforts to bring peace to Kyrgyzstan and to establish stable political conditions. Let us engage in this debate and vote tomorrow.

We not only declare our resolve but also follow it with actions, so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we will not leave them alone on their path into the future or deliver them into the hands of undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else entirely.
That is completely incomparable.
Cloning is animal cruelty, and many colleagues have already stated this here.
I also mentioned this before the summer break in the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
and those who survive, many, many of them die very, very early, and indeed, in great agony.
suffer from malformations of extremities of organs
They have immune deficiencies; they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering, and precisely this agonizing death.
Can we really take responsibility for that?
We advocate so strongly for animal welfare, and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is also only consistent.

Yes, we are aware that products derived from cloned animals or their offspring are likely not harmful to health, and I personally believe they would indeed be suitable for human consumption. However, there is in fact no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why then should we engage with this clone?
It is entirely unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. The population simply does not want it either.
The population does not want these products, and we do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
Therefore, we advocate for a distinctly clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and indeed also for their offspring.
I advocate for a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course, I must also refer to imports.
I want to be certain that cloned meat is not covertly slipped into my food without labeling, as has already happened here.
I don't think, and I believe it's not possible to trace all meat back to its origin.
The beef market is possible.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether there was actually a clone in the ancestry.
Fundamentally, I think yes, it is a principle-based question, it is an ethical question.
And colleagues have said, We must also address ethical questions; we are also responsible for ethical questions.
Of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but it is also a different issue.

Experience shows that as a livestock producer who has studied this field, all reproduction techniques, once they have proven effective in animal production, ultimately find their way into human application.
So we must ask ourselves today: Do we want and are we able to employ cloning technology in the not-too-distant future? Do we want and are we able to accept this for humans as well?
So I don't want to, and I also can't.
And even if, in the future, a clone might be able to donate a vital organ, a clone of myself, I would not want that.
I do not believe that this is an exaggerated horror scenario.
I believe that this could be possible in a not-too-distant future if we were to allow cloning.
Therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on clones and their offspring throughout the entire EU.
I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We do not have to imitate everything the U.S. does, despite all transatlantic friendship.

Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues,

I have an issue with parts of the debate.

When we discuss mountain regions and sparsely populated areas, I get the impression from certain contributions that they are considered extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that's not how it is.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which is sovereign.
The implementation of European decisions and objectives, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, remains the responsibility of the member states.

When considering the European level, we have always paid particular attention to these areasâ€”mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, and islandsâ€”as evidenced in the Communication from the Commission up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in the Parliament, too, many resolutions have been adopted to support this region.

When I hear many complaints here now that there are still deficiencies in the regions, the question arises for me: How have the member states dealt with the impulses that we have sent from the European level? How have they addressed them?
And how have the regions themselves approached this and utilized the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is being demanded here. I feel sorry for the officials of the DGRego Lei, who are expected to encapsulate the myriad problems of islands, mountainous regions, and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies for the Danube, the Baltic Sea, the Black Sea, climate change, and so on and so forth, to the point where we will soon need a strategy for strategies in order to maintain an overview.

Dear colleagues, fun aside! I believe the real issue at hand, and this was also stated today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for mentioning it, is that we must fight to ensure that there will still be a cohesion policy and a regional policy at European level after 2013.

Cutting costs to the bone in entire economies might be to the taste of European funds and banking crises. But it helps neither Ireland, nor the currency union, nor the ECB.
Mr. Prich, do not heed Ms. Merkel's simplistic finance!
If you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Euro Banks before the next speculation victim falls!

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner! Considering how we debated this Commission proposal during the last parliamentary term, from total rejection to jubilation over all the wonderful things coming our way, I must say I am enthusiastic about what we have before us now.
The rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs are greatly commended for synthesizing a coherent opinion from this wide range of views.
I believe the magic word lies in the focus on the patient.
One has not, therefore, taken the many receptor phenomena and said, "What does the patient need?"
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can inform themselves through various means and not just one.
However, I would like to emphasize that the doctor will continue to be the patient's trusted advisor and will undoubtedly have an influence on crucial matters.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been checked and approved by a regulatory authority.
This ensures that the information is scientifically validated, and thus the patient can safely rely on it.
Of course, it is correct that not everyone can determine it.
There are various ways to access the internet, and I believe it is so widely available that we need not worry about it.
I only hope that the Council now finally has the courage to tackle this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
I believe then that we have accomplished a great deal for many!

Mr. President, Mr. President! There was an incident during the debate on the European Council that is worth mentioning, although I do not wish to dwell on it further, as I was the target of an insult.
I would like to point out that there are levels on which I cannot be offended, and where I do not perceive it as an insult, because to offend me, one must possess a certain degree of sincerity.
I would, however, like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless signs of solidarity I have received here in this house since then.
I would like to express my sincere gratitude to all of you, dear colleagues from all factions.

For that, my sincere thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. GÃ¼s, dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs,

I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system will be placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that contributed to the crisis.

I would like to make a remark on this, dear Mr. Vannier. The selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the effectiveness of these new authorities largely depends on the quality of their personnel.

I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, expertise and independence from the financial industry they are meant to control, a clear commitment to public interests, will truly be the driving factors, and that we will not once again see national quotas in the selection process that override these important criteria.
Moreover, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack genuine transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in the regulations governing the financial industry.
We face severe conflicts of interest, we clearly have market power due to three dominant providers, and we bear no liability for negligently produced ratings.
Therefore, Commissioner, it is encouraging that the consultation is now underway, and we eagerly await the outcomes.
I too believe that civil society in particular should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as brave as before, and let us jointly create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the ratings market in a European manner.
That is what we owe to the citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, colleagues! The past few months since the beginning of this year have demonstrated the potential harm that rating agencies can inflict.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
Therefore, I welcome, or rather, I welcome the directive insofar as it assigns supervision and registration of rating agencies to ESMA.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and constructive proposals were lost in the negotiations over the report.
I would like to note this here.
The mandate of ESMA thus remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database to create ratings have been dropped. Similarly, there is no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.

The Commission had further proposed promoting unsolicited ratings to overcome the disastrous situation of commissioned ratings for the evaluation of financial market products. Nothing has come of that either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the upcoming reports on this topic, which Jean Paul Grosset and you, Mr. Vannier, have both mentioned.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues! Firstly, let me also express my gratitude to those who have worked on this report, especially to my colleague, Mr. Benson!
I would like to draw attention to two perspectives and perhaps give you something to ponder.
We agree that energy efficiency, using energy sparingly, is the simplest and most reasonable solution.
The question is, How do we achieve this goal?
I would like to pose the question: What has actually been achieved by our continually approaching the people in Parliament with new and higher percentage figures?
Have we truly achieved more and made a greater impact?
Or why and at which points has energy been used more sparingly?
I learn that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, deals with energy sparingly because it saves money that way and because it is advantageous for them.

I am learning that people, when they know that this device consumes more or less energy, will make a decision based on what they perceive as a personal advantage. If they see the energy consumption and recognize a benefit for themselves, they will opt for it.
It is not about correctly using percentages, but rather about effectively employing incentives to make progress.
Second Question The Commissioner has just presented very compellingly and clearly how complicated it is to even describe the concept, "What is it actually?"
How differently does this occur in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states are in vastly different situations economically, geographically, and in every other respect.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding figure, or do we need to come up with something more?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to break away from the past debate, which relies on simple figures, binding targets, and miracle solutions, thinking that they can achieve something. Clearly, we have not accomplished enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach of differentiation, offering diverse responses that cater to the various situational nuances, while also ensuring an impact is made.
It is the effects that matter, not our personal feelings.

It is important that the EU addresses the issues of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is no precise analysis available regarding the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any mature calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
The examination of reality, however, also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for completely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration to the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers are not given the opportunity to profit in the billions from the fate of humans by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and meticulous manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission has provided for corresponding obligations in the new regulations.
I consider many of these to be correct, such as interpreters, proper medical treatment, and taking into account special vulnerability.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
Member state authorities are provided with far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of conducting accelerated proceedings and summary proceedings should be restricted to a reasonable extent.

If an applicant flagrantly breaches their duty to cooperate, there are hardly any sanction options available, quite the opposite. If they go into hiding illegally, the member state should no longer be able to conclude their procedure negatively. If they reappear, they should have an extended range of procedural options at their disposal.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an accelerated procedure should be possible after the second subsequent application.
This entails significant cost increases.
Even the free legal advice in the form of a lawyer, according to the Commission's draft formulation, currently represents a significant cost increase for the states.

I simply and urgently request that the Commission reconsider the consequences of its proposals in terms of practical reality, financial implications, and the challenges they pose for the administrations of the Member States.
We aim for a high standard, but it must also be achievable and, in particular, not place excessively burdened member states before completely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor briefly once again.
I have a great request of you, Commissioner FÃ¼le.

We are currently not seeing a decrease in the number of asylum seekers, but rather a significant increase.
This is related to visa facilitation measures, for example with regard to Serbia and North Macedonia.
We are currently also witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from the false assumption that costs in subsequent instances would be saved by disputing the first-instance procedure in a higher-qualified reform, one automatically assumes that all member states, as it were, have a poor first-instance procedure.
That, however, is not the case.
Raising standards across the board ultimately means that cost increases will result from this.
An increase in quality standards for all involved, as well as the complication of processes, inevitably leads to higher costs in practical reality. I am open to discussing this.
Therefore, I once again kindly urge you to take the concerns of the countries seriously, as the practical reports from the countries are partly of lasting value.

Mr. President, dear colleagues,

This report attests to the Commission's successful competition policy.
It must not be forgotten, however, that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the widening gap between rich and poor.
Unrestricted competition in the European Union still takes precedence over the social needs of the people.
The credo of free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of permanently establishing social justice.
A few proceedings concerning distortions of competition and price-fixing do not solve this problem at all.
A fair and at the same time social internal market only functions with strong and just regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.

much stronger consumer protection, the exemption of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartels. All of this is urgently needed.

Ladies and gentlemen! This is a truly significant moment as we commemorate the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament today.
Let me begin with the farewell letter written by a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, in 1943, before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again.
We are en route to the concentration camp.
I have come to terms with my inner self to the extent that I can bear death.
I would like to express my gratitude once again for everything you have shown me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven!
Your Robert!

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy, along with 500 other Roma and Sinti, did not return. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrial-scale mass killings, even 66 years later, the full truth about this remains unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is often concealed as well.
We need the full truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against Roma and Sinti must be punished as a crime against humanity and acknowledged to ensure that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must counter racist hostility and violence, as occurred, for example, in Hungary two years ago, with unity and civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not the privilege of a few, but the right of all, for human and civil rights are indivisible.

We are dealing with a rather enormous influx.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

achieves results for people, secondly ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly takes into account the particularities that this is a transport sector largely shaped by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This removes the extreme demands that would have made bus services almost entirely impossible due to excessive requirements, as well as demands that would have excluded the majority of member states from the scope of the regulation entirely.
Public bus services, which benefit the general public, must also provide high-quality transportation for people with disabilities and those with reduced mobility.
You should have a right to assistance, and in the interest of social integration, this should be provided free of charge.
Madam President! I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Kanzan, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of brokering a compromise on this challenging file.
There were successes, which have already been listed, but there were also disappointments, such as for example the scope and other subtleties that have already been presented.
With this compromise on bus traffic, we have covered passenger rights for all transport data.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent, and efficient framework program for all passengers.
