Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues! We are in the midst of a major economic crisis. We have been talking about this for months, and that is all true. But typically, we discuss it in terms of headlines and then continue to make decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because even we in the parliament are not specific enough and not honest enough in our actions; instead, what we have is a policy of catchy headlines.
What, then, truly drives growth and stability?
Let us also contribute to handling our finances more responsibly and wisely.
Do we truly examine critically whether we are making the right expenditures, or doesn't each one of us have a new idea every day about where we can spend more money?

If we do not have the power to focus the funds on future projects, and that means conflict and debate and decisions, it makes no sense to talk about innovation and research but not provide the means for it.
This is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that encourage economic growth, rather than spending every waking moment considering how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We continue to cheerfully pass resolutions, constantly demanding new ones today that disrupt the economy in its developments.
Would anyone believe that addressing the issue of binding energy efficiency targets is merely one example of contributing to the advancement of the economy?
Do you truly believe that the decisions we have often made in relation to energy have stimulated the economy?
Or have we disturbed them.
I would like us to be a bit more honest about this and make fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move us forward.
This is more arduous, more laborious, and will also lead to disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! The call for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years now, opponents of globalization have been demanding such a tax.
Yet just five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be feasible in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda of the European Parliament along with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
The financial instruments that Annie Polimamata proposes in her report are ones that I can only welcome and support, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
These are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has so far focused solely on cutting expenditures.
Cutting public spending primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poorâ€”in other words, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
She is the second lever that can be adjusted to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, the main causes of the public debt crisis and the repayment of public debt can also be adequately addressed through the revenue side.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high indebtedness of public budgets is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of the debts of private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis by no means rests solely with the states.
It is therefore not only obvious but also politically necessary to make the financial sector pay its fair share.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be involved in contributing to the repayment of public debt, as the main cause of such debt.
This is an important political signal that this report sends, if it is adopted as presented.
However, we also consider Eurobonds to be a meaningful and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints from some surplus countries that their interest burdens are increasing due to Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also profit from their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
Those who want a social Europe, those who wish for the EU to remain united in the future, must at least in principle agree to a transfer union.
In conclusion, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that you will now finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax, which has been demanded for over a year.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! The rescue packages were intended to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are imposing brutal austerity measures on people while leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Furthermore, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.

The European Union was never a project for a race to the bottom in terms of wage competition and social dumping.
There is talk of rigidity in wages, which is to be reduced. There is reading about it.
That is to say, wages should reflect market conditions.

They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the well-established autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.

I would like to make it clear that this parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent the further erosion of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policy actions. I thank you.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner K Cruz, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration for the broader societal implications.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program holds a particularly significant role.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be utilized to the fullest extent across all frequency bands, in order to generate maximum efficiency.

Based on the radio frequency policy, the telecoms package adopted last year must be implemented, as it also stipulates that EU and member state radio frequency management must equally serve cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into particular consideration when harmonizing frequency usage in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I is being carried out at very different speeds in the member states.
Further opening of the URF band, especially below 800 megahertz, should therefore be considered only after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions are still not definitively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical conversion process, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
In the allocation of frequency bands, the differing interests must be responsibly balanced against each other.

Universal access to mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. At the same time, however, further development in the field of public and private broadcasting as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity must also be taken into account.
We must set the right course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I would like to say first of all, as you have described it, the situation has deteriorated.
The eurozone is experiencing a divergence between countries that are recovering and those that are faring weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are rising ever higher.

In this situation, I have some questions for you. As the Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: On a daily basis, customers of the ECB system have accumulated liabilities and claims between the central banks amounting to over 400 billion euros.

When will the Commission present this?
And how do you, as the Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then, as we Greens have been predicting for some time, the measures against Greece and Portugal are not working, as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the eurozone do not improve.
We are still seeing absolutely rising interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We are witnessing increasing capital outflows and capital flight in some of these countries.
We are still experiencing a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Eurozone countries.
And we are seeing rising resource and food prices, at least if we discount the recent ups and downs.

I wonder, alongside the bailout for these countries, and the financial aid, what measures are being taken to enable the weaker nations to exert macro-economic control on these fronts: the front of external demand, and in terms of interest rate relief?
And how
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that macroeconomically improves the conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

Ultimately, in my view, the measures have affected the weakest in the countries of Greece, Portugal, and Spain, contrary to the spirit of the EU Treaty. Meanwhile, the stronger, the wealthy, have so far not been made to bear any part of the burden.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, and dear visitors,

The cultural diversity of Europe is a valuable asset that we must preserve and continue to foster in the future.
To make this possible, we must face the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the field of the cultural and creative sectors.
Cultural diversity is not only an idealistic value but also a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately two and a half percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many areas of the rest of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content provided by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of this content have been transformed and enhanced by technology.
We therefore need framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that enable them to develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also pay attention to this area in the context of school and vocational education.
We need to impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
We must also strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators, not just their entrepreneurial competencies, but also their media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions that enable artists to earn a living from their cultural creations.
Therefore, we will have to deal intensively with questions of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, but also with the issues of open access to information and content, in order to

to ensure the future of the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment and to preserve the cultural diversity and cultural heritage of Europe as an essential feature of the European Union.

We consider the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
A particularly grim pinnacle was reached by the deportations in Europe in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.

We must also not forget that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsion.
We must demand a serious confrontation with the various forms of expulsions and the bogus justifications.

I had the opportunity, as a parliamentary election observer, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan, and I was impressed by the overwhelming consent of the South Sudanese to determine the fate of their country themselves in the future.
I also witnessed the great expectations among the people, who viewed their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called internally displaced persons, driven from their homes in the south by decades of conflict and sheltered in refugee camps in the north, are now embarking on the journey back to their former homeland in South Sudan.

Of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the independence of their country, above all desire to walk a path towards a happier future in the context of peace, after all the decades of warlike conflicts in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is set to become officially independent, expanding the family of nations in our world.
The state of affairs is utterly dire, and much has already been said about it here.

Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues,

After nearly three years of intense work, after far more than three amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

Debates After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it now stands for voting: The political package, the great compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also intended to benefit.
Legal certainty, the end of bureaucracy, and better regulation are the goals.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and it is crucial to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must fit every food and non-alcoholic beverage, from staple foods to highly processed ready-to-eat meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labeling system using traffic light colors is not feasible, as this type of labeling simply does not apply to staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in the Parliament, and despite the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved can certainly be seen as a notable accomplishment.
Allergens will be immediately recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is stated.
There is a country of origin labeling for pork, poultry, sheep, and goat meat.

For further products, an impact assessment will indicate whether and how the origin can be specified, for example, for milk and milk products, single ingredients, i.e., products consisting of one main ingredient, meat in processed goods.
Products, etc. that are imitations must be clearly labeled on the front, and the same applies to formed meat and formed fish composed of, and glued together from, small pieces.
A package must not give the impression that it contains something that it does not.
If an image of fruit is on a yogurt, it must also contain fruit, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, there is the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first freezing for meat and fish, and many more details.
The most important thing, however, is that all information must be legible.
We have defined readability, established a minimum font size, and mandated the commission to set binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we are protecting the craft from high costs and bureaucracy.
Unpackaged fresh products must provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information, which would require costly analyses.
The Commission initially sought this, but it would have destroyed national and regional peculiarities and specialties, leading to a European homogenization, which is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the reputable consumer protection organizations are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues,

Given the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
Only in this way can we restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report focuses on the strategy to prevent infinite human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 annual deaths and over [number] injuries.
5 million often severe injuries resulting from road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of an associated economic loss of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone corresponds to the number that would be expected from the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized passenger aircraft.
What would we not do to prevent that?
The accident-related costs exceed the annual overall budget of the European Union by a significant margin.
Therefore, I am confident that it is beneficial for us to engage in sustainable activities in this field.

Thanks to the constructive work of all shadow rapporteurs and many colleagues, we have succeeded for the first time with this report in developing a holistic, coherent approach to improving road traffic safety.

It takes into account the contents of the UN Decade of Action for Road Safety 2010 to 2020 as well as the content and objectives of road safety work in the EU member states and broad sections of civil society.
It encompasses, firstly, ambitious yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020 and, with the vision SEERROM, for the period beyond.
Thus, by 2020, the number of fatal accidents is to be reduced by 50, the number of children killed by 60, and the number of seriously injured people by 40.
This is in the utmost interest of each and every one of our people, as well as in our national economy.
We recommend that member states adapt goals and methods to their territories and expect them to develop their own road safety action programs.
Secondly, it encompasses who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In line with the principle of subsidiarity, the holistic approach entails that Member States, regional or local authorities, and even individual road users, in accordance with their duty to cooperate, all have a responsibility to act.
Thirdly, it encompasses how, that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not wish to do without recommendations, guidelines, and commissions.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity. This means that competencies and responsibilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

Since, however, you come from the most diverse directorates-general such as transport, economic affairs, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, you are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradictory.
Therefore, we propose the establishment of a coordinator for road traffic safety within the European Commission.
This effectively prevents the establishment of a road traffic safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data definitions and statistics.
We therefore demand, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as the EU-wide exchange of data while safeguarding a high level of personal data protection.
Six main areas of action have been identified.
They concern humans as participants in traffic, road traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructures, their intelligent networking, as well as the particular consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.

Thank you very much, Madam President. There is no doubt that this House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizen.

Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are being ignored. The protection of competitive procedures, sensitive and personal data is being disregarded.
This is a serious breach of data protection, for which we otherwise always advocate so strongly in other areas.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
The present report poses precisely this risk, as administrative processes and decisions, including, for example, personnel matters, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition law proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access to such documents as well. For, as a document, it defines all data and content that are in any way related to the policies, measures, and decisions of all organs and institutions of the EU.
This includes, to a large extent, preparatory, confidential, and secret documents as well as all related information.
This definition thus encompasses not only document but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, should also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, for indeed, what that means?

It means public access to the process. It means public influence on the decision-making procedure. Then we might as well invite the lobbyists to the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizen wants?
I cannot imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative bodies, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in this?
Or would it rather hinder our work?
I believe this report is not in line with the interests of our citizens.
It would trigger a flood of useless information.
He would render our work impossible, and above all, as you have heard from the Commissioner, he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur. In essence, you are working against greater transparency and against the citizen. Thank you.

Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! When dealing with such an important and relevant topic as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, there is always a significant risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three desired issues.
When one considers the result that will be put to the vote tomorrow, one can without doubt congratulate our rapporteur Matthieu Grosch.

He managed to distill a good, coherent, and comprehensive result from several hundred proposed amendments, one that places the main emphasis for the future of transport on security, environmental protection, energy, and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also adequately addressed here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming shortage of skilled workers in the transportation sector, which must be actively addressed if future bottlenecks in highly qualified personnel are to be prevented.
Further opening of cabotage in road transport must be conditional on preventing social dumping and unfair conditions.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
Road safety is an issue that must continue to concern us in the future as well.
I view other points more critically.
I would have liked to see a statement on the model ship that emphasized shifting more traffic from roads to rails and waterways.
For this reason, I do not believe that the discussion about Gigaliners is the best solution for greater sustainability.
Similarly critical is the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport, which should be monitored and reconsidered.
There are still technical harmonizations and fair competition conditions to be addressed here.

As stated in this report, I hope that the expectations of Parliament expressed here do not remain a mere pious wish, but that a goal is achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality. Many thanks.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! It surprises me that we continually need to remind ourselves of what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and by definition, it aims to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, with a particular focus on promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
In many regions, the situation looks even more challenging regarding economic development if these funds were not available.
The implementation of the funding structure is based on operational programs, as previously mentioned, which outline the funding strategy for each respective region.
The European Union, its Member States, and regions work in partnership here, thereby creating a genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy also depends on the reliability of the programs and the funds made available and committed.

Therefore, I am greatly surprised when, time and again, member states and also the Commission, as we are seeing now, attempt to utilize Structural Fund resources like a piggy bank for all manner of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the purpose and aim of cohesion policy, and moreover, it unsettles the stakeholders in the regions who are already working towards achieving these goals based on long-term strategies and agreements.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important objectives.
This can only be achieved, however, if the partnership cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
For only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the fundamental partnership and solidarity bond of action between the different policy levels in the European Union.
In it, the solidarity of Europe becomes tangible in the regions, and it should not be recklessly abandoned due to political quick fixes.

Dear colleagues! The discussion in this house shows that we essentially represent the full spectrum, on the one hand, those who do not wish for any restrictions, and on the other hand, those who associate every form of immigration immediately with the risk of mass immigration.

I believe that family reunification must be viewed with a great deal of reason and rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed issues in member states where overly restrictive measures are being taken.
For family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited at all.

On the other hand, it is entirely justified for Member States to require, for example, language skills from member states, to demand integration, but also to demand the willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States do indeed have the right, and we should not brush aside these issues, to articulate the problems that arise in family reunification.

If countries like Greece or like Malta, or indeed like Romania or Italy, are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they partly face in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic when we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need another new guideline right now.

When an amendment to the regulation on biometric passports in 2009 required a review after three years and the presentation of four studies, our faction supported it.

we have now been able to determine.

Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone, with less protection and fewer rights.
