Sincere thanks for that.

Numbers often speak louder than words, and to date, the European Patent Office has granted nearly 2,200 patents on plants and almost 1,200 patents on animals, which were created with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I may mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents for genetically modified and conventionally bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Affected are our farmers just as much as our brewing producers, as well as we consumers.
In my opinion, this example illustrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called LongLiTo, not to be confused with its LongLi oil, which you have in the engines of your diesel engines.
With this trick by the applicant US corporation Arcadia, this patent was granted in circumvention of valid EU rules.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This demonstrates the type of Drexel being used, even though, as you stated, Commissioner, it is clearly stated in Article 4 of the 1998 Biopatent Directive that plant varieties and animal breeds are not patentable, and that essentially biological processes for the production of plants or animals are excluded from patentability.
We are of the opinion that this definition needs to be clarified and must be interpreted precisely.
Technical methods employed to support conventional addiction treatment should not collectively render patentability.
We specifically say no patents on life.
We need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with creation, once again against the patenting of life across Europe.
Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: no patents on life.
Thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many breeders and farmers across Europe, we call for a clear enshrining of the breeder and farmer privilege throughout the legislation. Thank you.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to address the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol, there is little to nothing to criticize.

The annual financial statement accurately reflects the financial position in 2010 in all material aspects, and all underlying transactions were conducted in compliance with regulations and are therefore lawful.
Notable are only the high transfers in relation to the overall actually low incurred costs.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters. This is, of course, understandable.
But Europol undertakes to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
In addition, Europol intends to commit to monitoring the implementation of the budget on a monthly basis starting in 2012.
I recommend that we monitor this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend discharging Europol.
The annual financial statement for Eurojust reflects the financial situation in all essential aspects for the year 2010.
Transactions here are also legal and in accordance with regulations.
But even here, high operating expenses were carried over into the year 2011.
After the establishment of EuroIst, this was primarily due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs related to data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better compliance with tender requirements.
I recommend that we also examine this in the future and, above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
This has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we may have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to Orrius.
I recommend nonetheless a relief. Thank you.
Madam President, highly esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! What should alarm and panic us is not merely the sheer number of unemployed youth in Europe, but the trend.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of unemployed youth increased by 26.5%, according to the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires action. For we are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we instill in young people a sense of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they are turning away from this EU, as they lack reasonable prospects for work and life.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are taken. I already see some progress, but please make sure that the long-standing intellectual stagnation does not now turn into operational panic!
When I read that the Commission is launching a program to financially support young people who apply for jobs abroad, we are merely creating a traveling circus that does not address the core issue.
On the contrary, it becomes counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff will then be poached from the wealthier states, those that are not in this crisis.
In this crisis, the cause of this development necessitates offensive measures, namely the dismantling of this austerity, which is hampering the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investments in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a realistic outlook on life.
Final remark: This youth unemployment is also incompatible with the absurd idea of raising the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I urgently request your thanks.
Colleague, you stated that everything speaking in favor of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you yourself presented highly speculative examples.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what your opinion is of these investigations by the Commission and the Commission's study, which very clearly states that up until now, the real economy has been inadvertently included far too little in its dependency on

the financial markets that 95 percent of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money, and that one can indeed turn the negative growth effect, previously discussed, into a positive one by making corresponding growth-promoting public investments.
Is this for them merely speculation, or would they argue that such a comprehensive, wide-ranging study by the commission is also justified and constitutes a strong argument?

Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! The financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years. However, I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She at least takes up the idea of taxing the financial markets and, above all, making them contribute to the costs of the crisis.
I believe this is a very important signal to the financial markets.
This is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
There were a whole series of actions, petitions, and written initiatives in a number of member countries, urging politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that the Parliament has achieved a great success with the majority that has endorsed this report, this tax.
Certainly, it is not sufficient to stabilize and restrict the financial markets as might be necessary. But I believe it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to explicitly appeal to the Council to take the voices of the citizens, both female and male, seriously and to advocate for them.
that there is a genuine introduction, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the Council, due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It now lies in the hands of the Council to act here, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this regulation is actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
dear colleagues, while we can and should discuss the various detail problems, which will also be addressed in the further legislative process, I believe we should agree on one fundamental point:
be clear. Financial markets cannot operate according to this model. When things go well, banks reap the profits, and when something goes wrong, taxpayers are left to foot the bill.
For this reason, it makes sense to subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the eurozone, we will not experience disruptions, but rather we will permanently contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for: enabling companies

Having access to capital in a way that allows savers to put something aside or to save for their old age, and that thus enables financial markets to fulfill the task they were once created for: to generate added value for the real economy.
All of the factors that drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

Therefore, it makes sense to consider a tax as a contribution to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is regulated, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its task.
I am advocating today, with a large majority, for this proposal.
The reform of the general system of preferences was indeed necessary.
It is now positive that there are longer deadlines and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has also stated.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to the World Bank classification.
In the past, the Parliament has repeatedly engaged in a very critical examination of gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross national product of 4 or up to 12.
This is thus an enormous and far too wide range, and it in no way reflects the realities on the ground.
That countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are discovering [something], we certainly do not find cause for concern.
The reform in this respect was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China are, on the other hand, countries with upper-middle incomes. We certainly do not need to worry about their graduation from the APS either.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer nations, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Until now, the Commission has also at least taken into account the vulnerability criterion, i.e., countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on the export of a few products and are very vulnerable from being overrated.
Why then did the Commission strike out this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji Islands, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the vulnerability criterion.
Why did the Commission not continue using the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
There is a suspicion that the Commission aims to coerce poorer countries into accepting less favorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, where the developing country status of a country or region would then no longer play any role at all.
There may, however, still be an opportunity for colleagues in the plenary to support our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also leads to the disruption of trade regions.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on development regions rather than individual countries.
Here, too, the Greens have tabled an amendment which, hopefully, will receive widespread support.
It is likewise problematic when countries that only yesterday benefited from the APS are suddenly to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and that a few months are not enough for economic development, we see in our own countries.

Ultimately, we representatives must also consider whether we want to rely solely on speed in all legislative initiatives and then work with hasty compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire plenary.
In my opinion, the entire parliament is essential for legislation in a democracy. What matters is not time or speed, but rather the time it takes to uphold democracy and properly enact laws.

Mr. President, High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observer mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I witnessed firsthand the immense hope and expectations for a better future that the people stood in line with as they waited to cast their votes at the polling stations.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as Colleague Nidelchev also did in her report.
The former President, Joseph Kabila, has declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again. Whether third-party states like Rwanda are involved remains unclear.
The victims in every case are the civilian population, who have been unable to live in peace and tranquility for decades now.
The wealth of the country is squandered in a maelstrom of corruption. The Congo remains near the bottom in all international assessments.

The international community of states, here in particular the European Union with its capabilities, must increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow genuine democracy to take root in the country. He must ensure this in the upcoming regional elections.
and that the Congolese army does not also harass the civilian population, but finally apprehends internationally sought criminals against humanity like Bosco and Ganga and brings them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to not delivering any further weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Lord, colleagues! With TuPEC, further intervention rights against crisis-ridden countries in the Eurozone are to be created.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policies, is set to bear fruit.
According to the Commission's intention, member states should be able to be compelled to accept financial aid.
With the Six-Pack, extensive sanctioning possibilities have already been created that can be imposed on Eurozone states with financial problems.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a meaningful economic policy coordination tool.
At the same time, the German government openly threatens Greek citizens with expulsion from the eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why do we not stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the euro crisis has once again dramatically intensified, as we see in Spain and Cyprus, it is not helpful to single out member states that are in crisis and blame them.
We should finally develop solutions. The TuPEEC rapporteurs have indeed proposed some meaningful approaches in this regard.
Certainly, Elisa Ferreira's suggestion of a redemption fund is noteworthy. This would be a worthwhile and meaningful measure to combat debt.
I also support John Paul Gose's proposal for an orderly state insolvency.
is, however, that Europe undertakes a joint and solidaristic effort to put the eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being self-satisfied and pointing the finger at their partner countries.
They must start doing their homework, invest in growth, and take on their responsibilities.
Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a crisis solution.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues,

In June 2010, the EU heads of government finally recognized that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
On the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union must not only focus on how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
A single market without coordination in wage and social policy presents member states with a strong temptation: to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can make the currency union not only economically but also politically unsustainable.
And the EU currently finds itself in precisely such a situation.

The German economy has undercut its neighbors for years, providing no stimulus through investments and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has driven the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is now slowly addressing this core issue of the euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making appropriate suggestions.

It is rightly demanded of the Federal Republic to invest more in education, research, and childcare. It is also entirely rightly demanded of the Commission to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a later, but important, insight.
I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you will strongly assert these demands against the German government, even though there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues! First of all, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, especially Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for the very simple reason that the experience from the last legislative period, prior to 2009,

The proposal, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening, was that the predecessor of Commissioner Barnier, Commissioner Merkrivi, essentially let company law fall into a deep sleep. For these five years, we have been dealing with this important issue, which is significant for the internal market.
have made progress.
Thank God, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a plethora of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been dealing with the issue of developing company law. We now have a very recent consultation with which, as Parliament, we of course also engage.
The Legal Affairs Committee has decided that we do not wish to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Mr Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make our position as Parliament clear, in a subsequent resolution, on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary, much like we had done previously about ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European company law, and this for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, literal gaps, which essentially result in the internal market not being achieved.
I wish to cite the example of the absence of the 14th Directive on the transfer of headquarters, which is typically a classic case illustrating such a gap.
The Parliament has twice called for concrete proposals from the European Commission on this matter in its legislative initiative reports.
There is also the expert panel, convened by the European Commission itself, which likewise held the same view on this matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms of the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat as well.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's previous statement on the 14th Directive falls significantly short of the Parliament's expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, as work progresses and if the action plan is adopted, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
Another important aspect of company law is the question of its further development with the aim of reducing burdens on companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example on the topic of...

Accounting

However, I believe that there is also more to be done and further aspects to consider, which will also be clarified in the course of the consultation.
Here we likewise expect further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the topic of the European private company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If there are individual member statesâ€”and I would like to state my personal opinion hereâ€”if there are member states within the EU that are unable to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of their own decisiveness.

To advance Europe, one must seriously consider, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation. This would ensure that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this matter more thoughtful consideration.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, essentially a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border matters in company law.
I also believe that this question requires further investigation and discussion, and would ask the Commission to do so.
This is also closely related.
The insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
In company law, there is much to be done in terms of regulation.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here and it is evident that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can then represent progress in shaping the internal market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Of course, one will also have to deal with the details. And that is something we will certainly have to do.
But also a very big thank you to the Commission.
We would, of course, be delighted if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and convert them into concrete proposals.
Esteemed Commissioner, I highly value your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But on the issue of the minimum wage, you caved to Mrs. Merkel, and I don't believe your promises regarding job creation in the healthcare sector.
How, please, is new work supposed to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?
How is employment in the health sector supposed to be created when the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester urge some member states to further reduce health expenditure?
I fear that this point in this plan is pure announcement politics, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a lack of remedies and medications not only in Greece.
I believe that those who continually roll out new bailout packages for banks must now advocate for a bailout package for the people, especially to secure medical care in the crisis-hit countries.
The mood among countless pro-Europeans like me is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is at least encouraging that what we are dealing with is now being stated much more clearly, and that Italy's role is also not being overlooked.
You yourself know that this involves a series of issues, not just those of debt and growth, but also those of trust and the trap of power, esteemed Commission, and also addressed to the Council.
Unfortunately, you have so far failed to address the central question of the separation of the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here, according to expert opinion, is continuously re-evaluated, meaning that no significant limits have been set on the shadow banking system.
Moreover, we are still faced with systemic risks. The issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to dwell on the rating agencies.

I can only urge you, as you work towards the Council summit, to also advise them to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the question of power between the real and financial economies.
In a nutshell, you are finally working credibly before the Europeans to ensure that banks are brought to heel and that citizens are not always left to bear the burdens.

For you, one can argue from the country that rejected the euro, with the central reasoning that they wish to preserve the flexibility of devaluation, precisely for socio-political instrumental reasons.

In light of the experiences you have now gained in Sweden, would you advise the Greeks to also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively employ this socio-political instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Thank you, Mr. President! I would also like to express my sincere gratitude to the shadow rapporteurs and the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environmental Committee with a clear majority of 62 votes in favor, no votes against, and no abstentions.
This demonstrates that we are actually standing very, very close together in these matters, including when it comes to compromises.

And the highest priority in these legislative procedures must, of course, be a high level of protection, a high degree of consumer protection, especially for the youngest members of our society, for vulnerable children.
As for gluten intolerance, this is a problem, and particularly so in kindergartens.
When one looks around, I have two children of this age, at the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we were right to take this approach.
We should then also discuss this in the second reading with the Council and the Commission.
I believe that we will then also achieve a good result.

Heartfelt thanks! A report about a traffic accident over the weekend, involving a truck driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into the roadside ditch, once again confirmed for me how necessary this is.
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control via the digital tachograph is essential for road safety, but also for the drivers themselves.
The digital roofographer represents a certain innovation. It presents new challenges, but also old problems.
The new challenges arise from new possibilities of manipulation that we must also master technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the context of control or a lack of control in various member states.
What we are now redefining, in my view, has essential aspects to consider. Firstly, it is not the case that every time a journey is not recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
For many drivers, loading and unloading is part of their job, and this, of course, should also be counted as working time.
The second problem is that the records of speed were removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, for there are also great dangers of accidents here.
We would also like to have weight sensors, and we would also like to have a hotline for reporting fraud, which is anonymous and can be tracked.
What I will also introduce is a motion to include animal transport inspections in this regulation.
I consider this to be important because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President! Many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have permanent disabilities if they had received professional medical assistance quickly enough, i.e., within the first so-called golden hour, after their accident.
We would be a significant step closer to the Vision Zero.
Now the ecosystem we are talking about today cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve one of the duty to provide first aid.
It solely serves, in the event of a severe accident, to automatically notify an emergency call center.
This must also establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle to prevent abuse and overload due to minor accidents.
What if the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds anymore, emergency physicians are sent to the scene of the accident with little but life-deciding information.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies with the member states for 17 years.
As long as the sensors integrated into the vehicle do not detect an accident, the ecosystem remains dormant, thus not transmitting any signals or data and also not being detectable.
It is thus also vastly superior to a mobile phone from a data protection perspective.
The system is activated either by automatic sensor-controlled opening or by deliberate manual triggering.
It then sends a pre-agreed minimum dataset of information to an emergency control center.
Uniform European standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and handled as emergency calls upon arrival.
Therefore, member states must also accordingly upgrade and expand their emergency medical service chains.

We want this universal emergency call system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency call number 2, free of charge for users, functional throughout the EU, and compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Through these, other intelligent public transport services can also be offered later, such as real-time traffic information or the availability of parking spaces.

In recognition of the outstanding achievements of the automotive industry in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their justification for existence in parallel with the public systems that have been passed.
Users can also opt for such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may be accompanied by costs, if necessary.
Temporary use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers.
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created today.

For if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilometers away from my place of residence, I no longer have a chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without having to buy a new tachograph, without there being new bureaucracy.

Therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, as I believe we should not place too much of a burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many positive points that we were able to include.
It was indeed planned to only accept fifty kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
a bit over 100 kilometers, yes, just about manageable, perhaps.
What if it goes beyond that?
In my opinion, it is exaggerated.
And one final aspect: as a representative of a labor organization in the CSU, I also say that with this regulation, we are creating complete control over employees.
Why?
because, for example, the person offering their goods for construction or beverages to breweries is monitored throughout the entire working day via GPS.
Therefore, I also consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable from a data protection perspective, and I would like to emphasize once again why I voted against it.
Sincere thanks for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision.

I awaited the consent of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still raising the necessary questions regarding legal certainty with respect to ACTA during the process.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
You did not want this. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used for delay. That is clear.
Why did I say that with the wide margin for interpretation?
One must, because you have asked two questions, answer both. Unfortunately, that's how it is.
because one can indeed read into and interpret from these broad formulations the surveillance of the internet, auxiliary police, and ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty, legal uncertainty does not help our economy either, dear colleague!
Mr. Leichtpreter, I would like to ask you: Are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
Or are you completely opposed to the rejection of all intellectual property?
How do you envision the adaptation of the E-Commerce Directive in the future to align with modern circumstances?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a debate on these matters altogether and do not support intellectual property.
Is that correct or what?
Lord! It becomes apparent that we are not merely dealing with individual facts that require discussion, but with the fundamental question: How do we stand on democracy and on civil liberties?
Let's take a look at ACTA, and we find that it is, in a sense, symbolic of opacity, lack of democracy, and violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.

and came about in an undemocratic manner, because the free use of the internet might simply no longer be possible and also because there would be no longer the freedom to use generic drugs to the same extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people took to the streets and effectively voted against ACTA long ago.
Yes, there has been voting on ACTA in the streets, on the internet, and in relation to the Petitions Committee in many countries, not just within the EU.
Even outside the EU, I believe we cannot ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only advise you to put ACTA to rest, that would be the decent thing to do.

Madam President-in-Office, as the rapporteur for the Budget Committee and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation had been awaiting action in the Council, and you have brought this process to a conclusion building on the results achieved under the Polish Presidency.
I would therefore like to thank two truly highly committed financial officials who have worked on these dossiers and also engaged with ambassadors.
I will miss him. His efficiency as a negotiator will be missed by all of us.
They have truly served the financial interests of the European Union.
Sincere thanks.
Mr. President, esteemed ladies and gentlemen! I am speaking here as a representative of my group and would like to support the motion put forward by my colleague, Mr. Fehlner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This demands a careful approach to the topic of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission, in order to clarify still outstanding questions, has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an advisory opinion.
I believe it is only respectful to the highest court of the European Union that we await this decision.
There is absolutely no substantive reason to make this decision today.
No one will be prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and opinion.
But the decision that is then made takes place within a different consciousness and a different understanding than we have today.
I do not believe that the "wrong-way drivers" on the Internet highway should dictate our policy. That is why I ask you to support this motion.
as always when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very insightful and one wishes that what he says would have much more influence on European politics.
I intended to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a sensible approach, but only if they are oriented towards sustainability and if political frameworks are also established for this purpose.
We are at risk of insuring dangers through guarantees that we do not politically control.

The Energy Transition in Germany

An 8,380-kilometer transmission network would be necessary, but so far, only 100 kilometers of these long-distance transmission lines have been constructed. This is due, among other things, to the resistance of citizens, interestingly, those who are very environmentally oriented.
We need to come up with something from the realm of politics.
One idea would be to create shared ten-corridors, combining not only high-speed rail tracks and broadband networks, but also constructing corresponding infrastructure networks alongside highways.
This, however, requires a much more comprehensive planning than has been foreseen thus far, but I would like to at least suggest it at this point.

Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that the borders of a country will always be a highly sensitive issue for our member states, and will remain so.
I am aware that the issues between member states concerning Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there exist various problems.
And ignoring the problems does not make them better, nor does it solve them more effectively.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and no one in our area would dream of wanting to cross the border illegally, just because we have problems.
But I also request the Commission's support in this area, not restrictions and reprimands.
The use of random identity checks has been established because we want to ensure security while maintaining freedom of movement.
When we conduct the dragnet operation successfully, I am particularly focusing on the borders with the Czech Republic, where not just a few drug dealers are involved, but rather...

We should try to facilitate a transition. In this regard, I deem it beneficial for the German Federal Minister of the Interior and the Czech counterpart to jointly address and resolve the issues persisting at the border.
And the Commission should not act in a regulatory manner, but rather positively and supportively.

We aim to put the populists in their place, but we must solve the problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to seek a solution with the Parliament, so that we can successfully adopt the Schengen files, ensuring freedom of movement and simultaneously guaranteeing the security of citizens.
The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also illustrate why the Council essentially wants to keep the Parliament out of Schengen matters.
The Council, in fact, continues to undermine freedom of movement without involving Parliament or any form of parliamentary oversight, and without any public scrutiny.
I can hardly wonder that you prefer to pat each other on the back in backrooms, away from uncomfortable questions.
No wonder the German government wants to completely rule out an evaluation of internal borders and thus doesn't even want to consider how much freedom of movement is being restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and thus also to the European Parliament. Thank you!

Dear Mr. President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofs, it is a special moment for me and my parliamentary group today to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
We are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person stands at the helm of the EU whom we count among our political family.
You are assuming the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges, and it is crucial to set the course for whether the
whether the union will actually have a future or whether it will prove to be, and this would be a historical defeat in my view, merely a footnote in history.

After the conversations we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairpersons of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are preparing for
We have prepared our presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the significance of your task. Apologies.
But, and you made this clear here today as well, you consciously want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of the people.
I can tell you here, after all that I have heard in recent years, it is the first time that a President of the European Union is doing exactly that, announcing it and stating it openly.

For a long time, I have missed this in official speeches: that it is being said that it is about the people, about those who are not responsible for the fact that we are in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It will be challenging to implement this precise approach.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am very confident that you will do this, if above all you encourage people with your presidency and in the way you lead.
Advocate for your rights and ensure that the Council and European institutions are aware of this very task.
We continually speak of the euro and its stability, of the necessity, which I also recognize, that it is important for the functioning of the European Union and the eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
For this, there were political conditions that were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union to accept a failing euro that forces people in the European Union to go hungry, that causes healthcare systems to collapse, and that compels local administrations to cease their work.
It has twisted itself.
It is not what we refer to as the goal of the European Union.
I fully support your demand that it should be about social cohesion and solidarity between the individual member states, as well as between the most diverse population groups.
The European Union should not continually allow itself to be used, nor should it present itself, as merely an instrument or a spokesperson for a small, specific segment of the population.

one final point I would also like to address, of course, to underscore that all of the priorities you have mentioned are important to us, and that we will support the points that align with these priorities, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
I believe that some decisions made in recent weeks and months, particularly during the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also influenced by fear.
And if those in power in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Wishing you much success in your work.
dear colleagues! I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs together.
It will be of the utmost importance for Ms. Colleague to work diligently and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

In this regard, all eyes are currently on us and on the Council to take this step and overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step of Europeanization, namely the establishment of a European Banking Union.
It should be noted that Parliament demanded this with a large majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been truly necessary.
Further billions in charges have arisen as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the consequences and wishes to further deepen this step for the eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has developed the proposals so quickly.
However, the Council's decision that the ECB should become the supervisor for the euro area is associated with certain difficulties.
In the Council, this leads to unanimity and it means that in this dossier, the Parliament is not involved in the co-decision process.
Based on the experiences with the supervision package, this is not acceptable.

Therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of the Parliament's democratic involvement.
Democratically, there are further challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If you are now to be responsible for banking supervision, the Parliament needs full budget rights, full oversight rights, questioning rights, and appointment rights. I am sure that the Parliament will also secure these by a large majority.
We will thoroughly address the complex issues surrounding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility in the coming weeks. Thank you.
By proposing to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to coerce these countries into free trade agreements.
These so-called Economic Partnership Agreements, as the term suggests, are not about free trade but solely about the interests of the EU, not the development interests of the partner countries.
This completely runs counter to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with this objective.
Countries such as Cameroon, the Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely impacted by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in southeastern Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
The South-South Cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and merely expect other countries to kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission truly believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Development Committee of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
We should join this in the plenary session.
Lord! In Central America as well as in Peru and Colombia, there are incredibly numerous problems in the area of human rights.
And we, as EU parliamentarians, cannot simply turn a blind eye to this.
We will thoroughly examine the human rights roadmap requested by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru once it has been developed.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of perpetrators and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the regulatory proposal for the safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue must then also confirm these points, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
The EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.

That is why we GREENS also demand a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, which does not just examine the economic impacts on the EU, but also, and in particular, the effects on human rights.
Mr. Barroso, I had already made clear in the first round what I wanted to emphasize.

I am concerned with the expectation of my faction that the Commission should once again fulfill its responsibility within the relevant bodies, in the form of a troika, to make this clear and explicit.
The Commission, as a European institution, stands against driving people further into poverty, against reducing working hours, and against undermining ecological and social standards.
This is your task.

If we succeed in making this clear, we will also send a signal to the people who are protesting in their thousands and hundreds of thousands in these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we as a faction also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
This morning, I heard the news that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we come to that people in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
I would like to add one more point: An approach held by many decision-makers goes like this: The people in Greece and other states have lived beyond their means.
We must be punished for it today and endure sanctions.
It is inadequate to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I am not attributing this to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, keeps recurring in my approach as well.
chairing I confess I have made a fatal mistake
I would like to make no statement on this report, but rather on the Morera report on the Agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to ask you to call me again.

Madam President! The new directive establishes a framework for handling books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are copyrighted but for which the rights holder cannot be identified or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be located may also be made available to the public.
And thus, a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Cultural Committee, it was of particular importance to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the cultural heritage of the European Union in this legislative initiative.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting institutions, there are countless, unexploited works, and solely because the rights of the owners are unknown, they should not remain unavailable any longer.
This changes with the directive.
In the future, it will enable the use of this cultural asset, provided that a careful search is also carried out prior to its publication.
This is a very important point to prevent the casual statement that we do not find in rights holders.

For a balance had to be found between the indeed real existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public as well to be able to use such works, where the rights situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where rights holders cannot be located, the draft enables the use of the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects such as Europeans and other major European digitalization projects, as well as our museums, archives, and educational institutions, along with public broadcasting, will flourish.
In the future, it must also be about making the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers accessible to the public as well.
This draft guideline and the compromise that has now been reached, in my view, truly represents a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that exists within it holds immense potential.
We should continue to work on this when revising the directive in two years' time.
Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President-in-Office of the Council! I would be delighted if the 2013 proposal also included clear
Signals from the Council would show us how we in Europe can enhance growth and competitiveness potential, and above all, how we can re-employ young people.
Could you please inform us which budget lines you intend to use here to promote youth employment and to prioritize entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
Or the Erasmus program for Young Entrepreneurs or the Media Plurality program. Here, there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by guaranteeing growth and employment in those areas where cuts are made?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be encouraged by the Council.
Where can this be found in the household budget presented by the Council?
The North Sea Works in Emmen were forced to declare insolvency last Wednesday as a guarantee from the Lower Saxon state government was unexpectedly not renewed.
This company, with 700 qualified jobs, is undergoing a transformation process from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass loan and that jobs can also be preserved. Because the Simon colleagues at SIAC and the North Sea operations have already had to accept significant wage cuts.

Therefore, I kindly request the Commission to examine this procedure with due consideration and promptness, to ensure that these 700 jobs are not put at risk. These 700 jobs are essential for organizing the energy transition and for developing future-proof energy sources in the seas of Europe.
Please do not let your colleagues there suffer due to the state government's poor crisis management.
Goods often appear harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes, enabling them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in their suppression of the Green Protest Movement.
Protectors were mass-imprisoned, dragged away, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example among many.
To add to this, the Commission, with its catalog of measures for an innovative and competitive security sector, as it is called, is promoting these dubious dual-use goods.
The goal is to achieve what is described as a better utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to approve all of our amendments and those of the Social Democrats.
I would like to ask Ms. Regner, what do you think trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment, for example in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will not be enough.
What active policy could the internal market contribute here?

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues,

I believe that with today's debate on MiFID, we are addressing the core area of financial market regulation.
In this legislative period, we have made progress, as it is about regulating financial markets and not just considering individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few keywords.
We didn't exactly make our work together easy last year.

We held a hearing in committee, conducted a survey of all stakeholders from all interested groups, and on that basis, developed a result using various processes, working documents, and the like, which we will present to the plenary for voting today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

We must, of course, acknowledge on the one hand that in recent years, significant steps have been taken in the financial markets. As a parliament, our interest lies in ensuring that every trade in financial securities takes place within the framework of the MiFID rules. This is why we also agree, under many conditions, to a new category.

We have agreed to the so-called organized trading facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, according to the provisions regarding order execution, transactions, and customer interaction, corresponding execution at the discretion of the institution can take place.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC papers that are traded will be traded within the MiFID framework.
Another major topic that was not yet taken into account in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here, too, our focus was on establishing clear rules, ensuring that this area, which can be highly dangerous and susceptible to manipulative use, is subject to strict regimes with minimum holding periods.

Trading interruption capabilities, with the ability to test algorithms, with the possibility of examining algorithms through a supervisory structure, through the introduction of a so-called TIC size regime, a minimum price size, and through appropriate fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of warning futures markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here when it comes to limiting the speculative element in true commodity markets so that we do not contribute, through false regulations, to a situation where people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford to buy food.
We therefore adopted a two-pronged approach, aiming to curb speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
By employing a Position Limit, with strict ceilings, on the number of contacts or positions, we aim to achieve this.
We also want to ensure, through a so-called "position che" system, that those who can prove they genuinely need a product do not suddenly enter this market speculatively.
Another topic that occupies us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would like to point out here that we have taken a very broad approach in ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The focus here is on identifying the needs of specific customer segments.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex securities.

It is about defining relevant products for target groups, conducting product tests, recording telephone conversations, providing appropriate advice, fulfilling disclosure obligations, andâ€”I would also like to briefly mentionâ€”applying subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member states should have the possibility, in accordance with their structures, to make appropriate adjustments.
I believe we are on the right track.
Once my time is up, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this.
I find it a shame that it is so difficult to ensure that everyone gets a four-minute speaking time.
I would like to express my gratitude to all my colleagues on the commission for their highly constructive role over the past few weeks and months.
I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council and hopefully finalize this important file as soon as possible. Thank you.
dear colleagues! First of all, many thanks for the generally good cooperation on this report.
We have a Commission proposal at key points that has already made significant strides in the right direction, which we can further improve.
In the realm of market structures, there will be increased transparency, particularly a more comprehensive transparency in the area of derivatives trading.

Within the framework of MiFID, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading in our compromise go far beyond what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have sparked significant public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, after great and difficult debatesâ€”this must be saidâ€”the new regulations are much stricter than the Commission's decisions, as position limits are now being enshrined as binding.
We still need further changes in this area, however, in order to close remaining gaps.
I also hope for additions through the plenary vote and ultimately in the trilogue.
And it is pleasing that Mr Barnier has already indicated his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
Where the report does have weaknesses, however, is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to ban products. This is a step forward. However, we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
Alas, the distribution of financial products is not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is strongly dominated by which product offers the highest commissions.
In Germany, and across the EU, consumers have lost significant amounts of money.
Think of the open real estate funds.
For citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be performance-based orientation.
Referring to subsidiarity here is a bit simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I can only say: Yes, what is long overdue is finally happening.
The report on the type approval of L-category vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought, especially longer than we had hoped. And there were far more obstacles than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere gratitude once again to the rapporteur, Mr. Van der Kampf, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we were able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that this report be approved. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
With better, my dear colleagues, I mean more certain.
For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and, consequently, the safety of drivers has always been a top priority, especially the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders.
The number of injured motorcyclists has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is declining, but this is not the case for motorcycle accidents in motorball.
Reducing the number of fatalities among motorcycle and scooter riders is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roadsâ€”that was, and still is, my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This topic must be thoroughly addressed, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies of anti-lock braking systems, or ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of the cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.
What we have achieved, however, is that as of 2016, all nine and as of 2017, all existing motorcycle types from 125 cc onwards must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer as a matter of course.
For motor scooters, manufacturers can optionally equip them with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, it must unfortunately be acknowledged that we have not achieved any improvement over the Commission's proposal.
I had hoped for much more from this. However, to put it mildly, the Commission and the Member States have been extremely sluggish.
What we have achieved, however, is that the Commission presented a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the Member States and is intended to examine the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
It will also be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in roller skates mandatory.
As you can see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will aim to close the binding gap in legislation starting in 2019.
I am confident that the data collected will vindicate my position.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheeled drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr. President, Matthias Groth, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe this also applies to what we are discussing today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in energy markets driven by unconventional resources, namely in natural gas, predominantly in gas, but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to fall into great euphoria about the supposed future of natural gas, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint grandiose horror and doomsday scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe that we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and consumers, and that the economic calculations of traditional energy sources are also being called into question.
We should face up to this development.

I believe that we should recognize that this could also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare to positively adopt and utilize new technologies, fairly weighing the opportunities and risks, and avoid falling into ideological debates. Thank you.
Commissioner, thank you for your response. It does not entirely satisfy me.
For I consider a period of one year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only then receiving a response to be a very, very long time.
I believe that a complainant who goes to the trouble, and usually they have already exhausted the entire legal process in their member state, deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If you do it in this form, we should also treat them accordingly.

I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates rights. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have no objection, if it serves the purpose, to attempting to reach a kind of consensual clarification with the Member States.
Only, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe, for instance, that proceedings are relatively swift in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a very large number of citizens demand action from the European Union, or also social rights, then it becomes a bit more cautious and laborious.
I believe that these facts, too, must be taken into account explicitly.
For your next report, I would like to see, as it were, a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis-Ã -vis the Commission, which are indeed explicit and effectively communicated.
Once again, if we truly want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so much procedure here in the European Parliament and in the Council,
We have jointly decided on this. We must then inform those who are responsible, those who are truly committed to a European approach, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great importance to me.
I will also closely observe again next time what has developed here.
Mr. President, colleagues! Five years ago, the EU's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
When one asks today about the balance sheet of this strategy, the assessment is mixed.
We observe how individual member states strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries in this region, while on the other hand, efforts are not progressing.
Accompanying states on their path of transformation towards modern democratic societies, or as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, a development that is even marked by setbacks.

Nevertheless, the European Union and its member states must therefore jointly assert their influence in this region more strongly, especially vis-Ã -vis Kazakhstan, which has meanwhile become a major supplier for several EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only result in competitors being able to exert their influence in this geopolitically important country, where the pressure to adhere to civil and human rights is not as significant, even more strongly than before.
The linking of economic interests with the commitment to upholding civil rights is the central aspect of the Central Asia Strategy.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation in this regard. Sincere thanks.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council! Perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's video stream, as it is clear that you lack both the capacity and the inclination to engage with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and today as a grave disrespect to the Parliament.
Instead of dodging this debate, you should rather reveal your secret as to why you resist any improvement in the protection of personal data in the police and judicial sectors through a directive.

Police and justice authorities have for yearsâ€”this is well-known in Eldoradoâ€”been guilty of violations in the area of data protection, not just in the case of SWIFT, but on a daily basis, for example, when data of citizens who demonstrate against Nazis is unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors and for the police and judiciary in order to be able to guarantee civil rights.

If the Council is expected to contribute constructively to data protection regulations such as those of the EU, PNA, or Europol, as requested by the Parliament, then this expectation must surely apply in reverse to the Council as well.
Therefore, I urge you to put an end to the blockade policy in the field of data protection.
